text:
I don't really like teaming up with sinners (looking at you engineers) that take pleasure in redefining holy numbers like `π`  to, let's say, `π=3` but can anyone properly explain what is behind the Julia approach that, as long as we don't use `π` we can assign it to something else
```# fire up a new Julias session
π = 3
# Congratulations, Archimedes of Syracuse is now crying```
```# fire up a new Julia session
pi = π
π = 3
# Congratulations, Julia just saved you from hurting Archimedes of Syracuse```
While writing this down I guess I kind of understand the approach, that is, allowing people who don't care what `π` really is being able to not have the symbol locked up to some irrational (pun) nonsense.

But why stop there then? I could be a masochist and not want `(+)`  defined as well...

_1 minute of playing with the REPL later_

HOLY SHIT, if you assign `(+)` before using any `Base` method you can also kill them
```# fire up a new Julia session
(+)(a...) = "nope"

# Congratulations, you have now made all mathematicians cry```
Writing this has been a revelation, I am in awe

```julia> (+)(args...) = (*)(args...)

6

julia> @eval Base 2 + 3
5```

```julia> 2 + 3
6

julia> Base.:(+)(2, 3)
5```
